instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..
definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message: Hi, have this really tough <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2012 retina board. It won't recognise a SSD even with a know good drive and known good caddy. All power lines at J4500 are present as expected. How do I properly check the data lines?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message:
Check all resistors and capacitors from page 37; as their traces too.
You should also try known good flex.
Chinese new can be crappy...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message:
By Caddy I meant the Plastic Caddy with its flex. Used one streikt from a working machine so that can’t be at fault.

I replaced <RESISTOR>R4506</RESISTOR>,4507,4508 and 4510 with ones from a donor as well as <CAPACITOR>C4522</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C4525</CAPACITOR>. I haven‘t replaced <CAPACITOR>C4518</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C4517</CAPACITOR> yet as they are so close to the PCH.

In regards to the traces, I traced all 4 SATA signals to their resistors and then capacitors but its not possible to trace them beyond that so a bad PCH or not properly soldered PCH could still in theory be a unlikely cause for this, can’t it?

What else to check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message:
"I replaced <RESISTOR>R4506</RESISTOR>,4507,4508 and 4510 with ones from a donor "
Was any bad?
Did you check if new ones have correct values?

Any history available?
Are you sure BIOS supports APFS (if is the case)?
Boot USB macOS and look in Disk Utility...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message: The drive isn’t APFS as it’s running Mavericks. None of the resistors were physically damaged or gave non nominal readings. same for the new ones. Don’t have any history on the machine. I did boot a copy of Catalina from usb and it didn’t recognize the disk.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message: Update: Someone told me it could in theory be a problem with the bios. I changed the SPI flash with one from my donor but that didn’t change anything

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on data lines and compare with good board.
Check on both caps sides, where is the case...
Do it w/ and w/o SSD connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message:
Here are some readings without the drive plugged in:

<SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_R2D_N</SIGNAL> - OL
<SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_RC_N</SIGNAL> - OL
<SIGNAL>SATA_HDD_R2D_C_N</SIGNAL> - .330
<SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_D2R_N</SIGNAL> - OL
<SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_D2R_RC_N</SIGNAL> - OL
<SIGNAL>SATA_HDD_D2R_N</SIGNAL> - .360
<SIGNAL>SATA_HDD_D2R_P</SIGNAL> - .361
<SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_R2D_P</SIGNAL> - OL
<SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_R2D_RC_P</SIGNAL> - OL
<SIGNAL>SATA_HDD_R2D_C_P</SIGNAL> - .333
<SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_D2R_P</SIGNAL> - OL
<SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_D2R_RC_P</SIGNAL> - OL


The only changes I found with a plugged in SSD:
<SIGNAL>SATA_HDD_R2D_C_P</SIGNAL> - .333 --> .332
<SIGNAL>SATA_HDD_R2D_C_N</SIGNAL> - .330 ---> .329
<SIGNAL>SATA_HDD_D2R_N</SIGNAL> - .360 --> .357

Seem to me like more of the tolerances of my meter...

Sadly have no know good board to compare with

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message:
I don't have any board to compare, sorry.
I don't see any strange value, but I'm not sure what should get on all data lines...
If there is a serie coil, check if is close to 0 ohm (internal resistance); even on power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message: Quick Question: Noticed there are 2 lines going to the SMC. Are they required or are they just used for monitoring or something?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message:
Did you check these lines too?
There are two pull-up resistors to verify.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message: Pull up resistors? <RESISTOR>R5068</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5067</RESISTOR> aren't actually populated...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> won't recognise SSD
threads.message:
Is true, NO STUFF; just saw it now.

You can suspect PVH issue now.
But should be good to compare all lines against working board.
